articles.headline: Russia to Open Airspace to U.S. for Afghan War
articles.snippet: The move is one of the most concrete achievements in the effort to rebuild strained U.S.-Russian relations.
articles.abstract: The move is one of the most concrete achievements in the effort to rebuild strained U.S.-Russian relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  The Russian government has agreed to let American troops and weapons bound for Afghanistan fly over Russian territory, officials on both sides said Friday. The arrangement will provide an important new corridor for the United States military as it escalates efforts to win the eight-year war.

articles.headline: Palin’s Move Shocks G.O.P. and Leaves Future Unclear
articles.snippet: Gov. Sarah Palin’s move shocked Republicans and fueled renewed speculation about her presidential ambitions and criticism of her political competence.
articles.abstract: Gov. Sarah Palin’s move shocked Republicans and fueled renewed speculation about her presidential ambitions and criticism of her political competence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska abruptly announced on Friday that she was quitting at the end of the month, shocking Republicans across the country and leaving both parties uncertain about whether she was leaving national politics or laying the groundwork for a presidential run.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Top Reformers Admitted Plot, Iran Declares
articles.snippet: The Iranian government has made it a practice to publicize confessions from political prisoners, often subject to sleep deprivation, solitary confinement and torture, rights groups say.
articles.abstract: The Iranian government has made it a practice to publicize confessions from political prisoners, often subject to sleep deprivation, solitary confinement and torture, rights groups say.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Iranian leaders say they have obtained confessions from top reformist officials that they plotted to bring down the government with a “velvet” revolution. Such confessions, almost always extracted under duress, are part of an effort to recast the civil unrest set off by Iran’s disputed presidential election as a conspiracy orchestrated by foreign nations, human rights groups say.

articles.headline: For Banks, Wads of Cash and Loads of Trouble
articles.snippet: Bulk deposits from brokers fueled growth at smaller banks, but also led some to the brink, and beyond.
articles.abstract: Bulk deposits from brokers fueled growth at smaller banks, but also led some to the brink, and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: MACON, Ga.  H. Averett Walker used hot money to turn Security Bank from a sleepy Southern lender into a regional powerhouse. Darrell D. Pittard used hot money to jump-start his brand-new MagnetBank, allowing it to lend hundreds of millions of dollars even though it did not have a single drive-up window or even a customer with a checking account.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Ire at Madoff Swings Toward the Referee
articles.snippet: Ever since the scandal broke, many victims have felt aggrieved at the process itself, directing their anger at a lawyer caught in a no-win situation.
articles.abstract: Ever since the scandal broke, many victims have felt aggrieved at the process itself, directing their anger at a lawyer caught in a no-win situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The victims of Bernard L. Madoff, who was sentenced to 150 years in prison on Monday for his heinous financial crimes, deserve our sympathies. Given where this column is headed, I should probably make that point right up front.

articles.headline: For Australian Winemakers, More Turns Out to Be Less
articles.snippet: Australian winemakers are selling more wine but making less money per bottle.
articles.abstract: Australian winemakers are selling more wine but making less money per bottle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  Just a few years ago, Australia was being hailed as the great international success story of the wine business, challenging the dominance of France, Italy and Spain. From 1999 to 2007, foreign sales grew more than threefold, making Australia the world’s fourth-largest exporter.

articles.headline: A Publisher Stumbles Publicly at The Post
articles.snippet: Katharine Weymouth decided to sell legitimacy, with her paper’s editorial integrity thrown in as a parting gift.
articles.abstract: Katharine Weymouth decided to sell legitimacy, with her paper’s editorial integrity thrown in as a parting gift.
articles.lead_paragraph: Katharine Weymouth, the relatively new publisher of The Washington Post, is a lawyer who worked for the company for 12 years and was educated at the Harvard School of Business, so she is hardly a naïf in running a business.

articles.headline: ‘Family Friendly’ White House Is Less So for Aides
articles.snippet: For White House aides, the demands of working for the president have made work-family balance elusive.
articles.abstract: For White House aides, the demands of working for the president have made work-family balance elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama talks up the family-friendly vibe at the White House  the nightly family dinners, the flexibility to attend school presentations and join impromptu plunges in the pool with his girls  his chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, sets him straight. “Family friendly to your family,” Mr. Emanuel counters.

articles.headline: Lead Us to Tweet, and Forgive the Trespassers
articles.snippet: Many churches are trying to embrace social media networks, but it has been an uneasy alliance thus far.
articles.abstract: Many churches are trying to embrace social media networks, but it has been an uneasy alliance thus far.
articles.lead_paragraph: Things went smoothly for the first hour of the Twitter experiment at Trinity Church in Manhattan on Good Friday in April.

articles.headline: So Many Foreclosures, So Little Logic
articles.snippet: Lenders lose much more money on foreclosures than on loan modifications. So why are they so hesitant to modify mortgages?
articles.abstract: Lenders lose much more money on foreclosures than on loan modifications. So why are they so hesitant to modify mortgages?
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week, the stock market tumbled on news that housing foreclosures and delinquencies rose again in the first quarter. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said that among the 34 million loans it tracks, foreclosures in progress rose 22 percent, to 844,389. That figure was 73 percent higher than in the same period last year.

articles.headline: Tax Bill Appeals Take Rising Toll on Governments
articles.snippet: Many homeowners are challenging their property tax bills as the value of their homes drop, threatening local governments with another big drain on their budgets.
articles.abstract: Many homeowners are challenging their property tax bills as the value of their homes drop, threatening local governments with another big drain on their budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Homeowners across the country are challenging their property tax bills in droves as the value of their homes drop, threatening local governments with another big drain on their budgets.

articles.headline: Were They Just Paper Airplanes?
articles.snippet: Students took out loans to attend a flight school that later collapsed. Then they pooled resources and hired a lawyer.
articles.abstract: Students took out loans to attend a flight school that later collapsed. Then they pooled resources and hired a lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOOKING back, students of the Tab Express flight school could see the danger signs.

articles.headline: Spinning the Web: P.R. in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Public relations gurus are courting influential voices on services like Twitter to endorse new companies, Web sites or gadgets, perhaps forever altering their roles.
articles.abstract: Public relations gurus are courting influential voices on services like Twitter to endorse new companies, Web sites or gadgets, perhaps forever altering their roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Menlo Park, Calif. — Brooke Hammerling (publicist) and Erin McKean (entrepreneur) are in a Sand Hill Road conference room, hashing out plans to unveil Ms. McKean’s new Web site, Wordnik.

articles.headline: Obama’s Youth Shaped His Nuclear-Free Vision
articles.snippet: President Obama is pushing for new global rules, treaties and alliances to establish a nuclear-free world, a vision he developed as a college student.
articles.abstract: President Obama is pushing for new global rules, treaties and alliances to establish a nuclear-free world, a vision he developed as a college student.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the depths of the cold war, in 1983, a senior at Columbia University wrote in a campus newsmagazine, Sundial, about the vision of “a nuclear free world.” He railed against discussions of “first- versus second-strike capabilities” that “suit the military-industrial interests” with their “billion-dollar erector sets,” and agitated for the elimination of global arsenals holding tens of thousands of deadly warheads.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Clerical Leaders Defy Ayatollah on Iran Election
articles.snippet: An important group of religious leaders in Iran called for the results to be thrown out, the most public sign of a major split in the clerical establishment.
articles.abstract: An important group of religious leaders in Iran called for the results to be thrown out, the most public sign of a major split in the clerical establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  An important group of religious leaders in Iran called the disputed presidential election and the new government illegitimate on Saturday, an act of defiance against the country’s supreme leader and the most public sign of a major split in the country’s clerical establishment.
articles.byline: By Michael Slackman and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: Unhealthy Fixation on Jobs’s Illness
articles.snippet: Last week, Steve Jobs returned to Apple, precisely when he said he would, but that didn’t stop the prurient demands to know the details of his health.
articles.abstract: Last week, Steve Jobs returned to Apple, precisely when he said he would, but that didn’t stop the prurient demands to know the details of his health.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Steven P. Jobs does his next big reveal, the geegaw people will most want to see probably won’t be on display.

articles.headline: Swings in Price of Oil Hobble Forecasting
articles.snippet: Government officials and analysts fear that the puzzling instability of oil prices could jeopardize a global recovery.
articles.abstract: Government officials and analysts fear that the puzzling instability of oil prices could jeopardize a global recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The extreme volatility that has gripped oil markets for the last 18 months has shown no signs of slowing down, with oil prices more than doubling since the beginning of the year despite an exceptionally weak economy.

articles.headline: ‘Tonight Show’ Audience a Decade Younger
articles.snippet: Early in Conan O’Brien’s tenure, the median age of “Tonight Show” viewers has dropped by a decade, partly because older people are tuning out.
articles.abstract: Early in Conan O’Brien’s tenure, the median age of “Tonight Show” viewers has dropped by a decade, partly because older people are tuning out.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the big questions facing Conan O’Brien was this: How can he succeed with the older “Tonight Show” viewers? The answer: by making them younger.

articles.headline: As Obama Visits, Russian TV Alters Take on U.S.
articles.snippet: In sync with the Kremlin, the Russian media have muted their criticism of the United States.
articles.abstract: In sync with the Kremlin, the Russian media have muted their criticism of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  When Barack Obama and Dmitri A. Medvedev meet behind closed doors here on Monday, among those on tenterhooks will be the television commentator Mikhail V. Leontyev, who has built a career on his relentless hectoring of the West.

articles.headline: Rise of Web Video, Beyond 2-Minute Clips
articles.snippet: Producers and advertisers are discovering that users, aided by the screen-filling video that faster Internet access allows, will watch longer videos online.
articles.abstract: Producers and advertisers are discovering that users, aided by the screen-filling video that faster Internet access allows, will watch longer videos online.
articles.lead_paragraph: When motion pictures were invented at the end of the 19th century, most films were shorter than a minute, because of the limitations of technology. A little more than a hundred years later when Web videos were introduced, they were also cut short, but for social as well as technical reasons.

articles.headline: Incandescent Bulbs Return to the Cutting Edge
articles.snippet: New energy standards are causing major innovation in incandescent light bulbs, a family of bulbs that some thought would not survive.
articles.abstract: New energy standards are causing major innovation in incandescent light bulbs, a family of bulbs that some thought would not survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  When Congress passed a new energy law two years ago, obituaries were written for the incandescent light bulb. The law set tough efficiency standards, due to take effect in 2012, that no traditional incandescent bulb on the market could meet, and a century-old technology that helped create the modern world seemed to be doomed.

articles.headline: On Facebook, a Spy Revealed (Pale Legs, Too)
articles.snippet: Online photographs of the new chief of British intelligence caused a little flurry of excitement in diplomatic circles.
articles.abstract: Online photographs of the new chief of British intelligence caused a little flurry of excitement in diplomatic circles.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  The man in the Facebook photographs seems like your average guy having a little fun. Here he is in a festive scene at a park, gamely wearing a red fleece and a Santa Claus hat. Here he is again, playing Frisbee on the beach, clad in a pair of snug bathing trunks that show off his muscular, if pale (he is British) legs.

articles.headline: Job Retraining May Fall Short of High Hopes
articles.snippet: As the stimulus plan directs large sums to retraining programs, there are questions about whether they work.
articles.abstract: As the stimulus plan directs large sums to retraining programs, there are questions about whether they work.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLINTON TOWNSHIP, Mich.  For the second time in three years, Mike Hutchins, a laid-off automotive engineer, is preparing to enroll in job retraining at a local community college, this time to become a civil engineering technician. But he has no idea if he has chosen the right path.

articles.headline: Despite Crisis, Policy on Iran Is Engagement
articles.snippet: The president and vice president said separately that the crackdown in Iran would not close the door on talks.
articles.abstract: The president and vice president said separately that the crackdown in Iran would not close the door on talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in separate interviews this weekend, said that the accelerating crackdown on opposition leaders in Iran in recent days would not deter them from seeking to engage the country’s top leadership in direct negotiations.

articles.headline: Court Ruling Clears Path for G.M. to Restructure
articles.snippet: A judge approved a plan by G.M. to sell its best assets to a new, government-backed company, a crucial step.
articles.abstract: A judge approved a plan by G.M. to sell its best assets to a new, government-backed company, a crucial step.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge approved a plan by General Motors late on Sunday to sell its best assets to a new, government-backed company, a crucial step for the automaker to restructure and complete its trip through bankruptcy court.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: China Locks Down Restive Region After Deadly Clashes
articles.snippet: Hundreds of protesters defied a government-ordered lockdown on Tuesday morning, a day after deadly clashes between Uighurs and Han Chinese.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of protesters defied a government-ordered lockdown on Tuesday morning, a day after deadly clashes between Uighurs and Han Chinese.
articles.lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China  The Chinese government locked down this regional capital of 2.3 million people and other cities across its western desert region on Monday and early Tuesday, imposing curfews, cutting off cellphone and Internet services and sending armed police officers into neighborhoods after clashes erupted here on Sunday evening between Muslim Uighurs and Han Chinese. The fighting left at least 156 people dead and more than 1,000 injured, according to the state news agency.

articles.headline: U.S.-Russia Nuclear Agreement Is First Step in Broad Effort
articles.snippet: President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev announced a preliminary agreement on cutting their stockpiles of nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev announced a preliminary agreement on cutting their stockpiles of nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  President Obama signed an agreement on Monday to cut American and Russian strategic nuclear arsenals by at least one-quarter, a first step in a broader effort intended to reduce the threat of such weapons drastically and to prevent their further spread to unstable regions.
articles.byline: By Clifford J. Levy and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Robert S. McNamara, Architect of a Futile War, Dies at 93
articles.snippet: Mr. McNamara helped lead the U.S. into the Vietnam War and spent the rest of his life wrestling with its moral consequences.
articles.abstract: Mr. McNamara helped lead the U.S. into the Vietnam War and spent the rest of his life wrestling with its moral consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert S. McNamara, the forceful and cerebral defense secretary who helped lead the nation into the maelstrom of Vietnam and spent the rest of his life wrestling with the war’s moral consequences, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 93.
